content: The indication is that you need to delete some of your messages to reduce your storage use.
creator: davidsk

content:
Yeah, I get that, but from where? Why do I have a limit? How much is it? How much have I used?

I have deleted some messages, but problem persists.
creator: thunderbird10

content: Your limit is imposed by your email provider. That would be the sum of your inbox, sent folder and any other folders you have online. Some email providers will allow more storage space for a fee.
creator: davidsk

content:
You'll have to add recipients to an address book in the first place. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1077025

Then you can create a new mailing list and drag and drop contacts from the address book to the list. https://kb.mozillazine.org/Thunderbird_:_FAQs_:_Create_Mailing_List#Create_a_new_mailing_list
creator: christ1

content: Thanks @christ1 - that was what I was hoping to work round! Thought there might have been a way to 'select all' of the 'to' addresses in an email and create a new list from it. Just that there are 60 emails to add to a new list :-(
creator: misterjat

content: The good news is, you can add contacts to an address book from an email message using the little 'head' icon at the right of each email address. It used to be a star in older versions of Thunderbird. So you don't have to manually type 60 contacts.
creator: christ1

content:
christ1 said
The good news is, you can add contacts to an address book from an email message using the little 'head' icon at the right of each email address. It used to be a star in older versions of Thunderbird. So you don't have to manually type 60 contacts.

Some small comfort I guess !

Thanks for your input.

content: Look at the email source (cntl and U keys) to see if that is true. Check also to see if you have set addressbook to always show name instead of email id. That is, it may be that your name is appearing only for you.
creator: davidsk

content: In old PC, - with Thunderbird not runnng, copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media - on new pc, with Thunderbird not running, copy the backed up Thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird folder - restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content:

Using the same (latest) version as it was in the old computer. Windows 11 Pro TB 115.8.1 64bit

I thought it might be an indexing issue, so I deleted the global-messages-db.sqlite file and restarted TB - no success. Deleted *.msf files - no success. Copied each folder individually - no success.
